title: Celtics reportedly trade Anfernee Simons to Bulls, acquire Nikola Vučević
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Celtics trade Anfernee Simons and a second-round pick to Bulls for Nikola Vučević and a second-round pick.
Vučević, a 35-year-old center, averages 16.9 points, 9.0 rebounds, and strengthens Boston's frontcourt.
This trade reduces Celtics' luxury tax penalty from $39.5 million to $17.7 million, helping their financial position.

title: What Mike Vrabel said of Robert Kraft’s latest snub from Pro Football Hall of Fame
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots owner Robert Kraft was not voted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame Class of 2026.
Mike Vrabel expressed support for Kraft, stating he is 'more than deserving' of Hall of Fame recognition.
Kraft has owned the Patriots for 32 years, leading to 23 playoff appearances and six Super Bowl wins.

title: Families of Revere women who died in Belize hotel file wrongful death lawsuit against resort, Expedia
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Families of three Revere women who died in Belize sued Royal Kahal Beach Resort and Expedia for $100 million in damages.
The lawsuit alleges carbon monoxide poisoning was due to a malfunctioning water heater, lacking safety measures like detectors.
Belize authorities initially suspected overdose but later confirmed carbon monoxide from a faulty heater as the cause of death.

title: She’s running Boston to raise money for Homes For Our Troops
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Rebecca Ludwig, 34, runs the 2026 Boston Marathon to raise money for Homes For Our Troops.
Homes For Our Troops builds mortgage-free, specially adapted homes for severely injured veterans.
Ludwig's campaign funds designing wheelchair-accessible homes, including widened doorways and adaptive technology.

title: Lawmakers urge Healey to  prepare for possible state prosecutions of federal officials
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Twenty-three state senators urge Governor Maura Healey to prepare for possible state prosecutions of federal officials.
The call is a response to federal abuses including shootings by ICE agents and reports of excessive force.
Proposals include a task force for federal abuse response and a portal for resident complaints against federal officials.

title: She’s running Boston to honor her sister — and the hospital that treated her
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Hannah Orzechowski Murray from Malden will run the 2026 Boston Marathon in memory of her sister Grace.
Grace was treated for glioblastoma at Dana-Farber before passing away, and Murray is raising funds for the hospital.
The marathon is close to Grace’s 30th birthday; the sisters shared a love for running and the Boston area.

title: Advocates, officials welcome judge’s move to block end of protections for Haitian immigrants
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: A federal judge blocked the Trump administration from ending Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for over 350,000 Haitian immigrants.
The ruling was a relief for Haitian communities facing deportation amid worsening conditions in Haiti, including a state of emergency.
Massachusetts Gov. Maura Healey emphasized the ruling's significance for the state's workforce, particularly in health care and caregiving roles.

title: What Robert Spillane and Harold Landry said about their injury statuses
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Harold Landry is recovering from a knee injury and anticipates playing in the Super Bowl despite missing the AFC Championship.
Robert Spillane, dealing with a foot and ankle injury, plans to play in the Super Bowl and practiced on Monday.
Both Harold Landry and Robert Spillane are listed as questionable for the Super Bowl, working towards being fit for Sunday's game.

title: Hundreds of apartments proposed for former Weylu’s site
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Developers propose a 300-unit rental complex on Route 1 in Saugus at the former Weylu's site.
Saugus' recent Safe Harbor status allows officials to potentially block the 40B project, exceeding 10% affordable housing.
Local residents oppose the plan, citing traffic concerns and impact on historic homes near the development site.

title: Ski Etiquette 101: What are your top do’s and don’ts for skiers and riders?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Skiers should follow the NSAA's 10-point safety guide, including staying in control and obeying signs.
Common etiquette issues include reluctance to lower chairlift bars, littering, and monopolizing lodge spaces.
Boston.com invites readers to share their tips and experiences regarding skiing etiquette via a provided form.
